bboxes.raw_text:
TUCSON The Committee for
Constitutional Rights announced
1t will soon test the constitution
atty of the recently passed city
public accommodations law.


Kent Winter, committee chair
man, said the test will be held
to determine whether the
ordinance is permissible under
the city charter.


The committee failed In it's at
tempt to get 3,444O registered
voters signatures on referen-
dunn petition. Winter said initia-
tive petitions will be out soon.


The public accommodations
ordinance prohibits discrimina-
ton of race, color, ancestry or
national origin in places of public
accommodation.

Tucson Group To Test
Aecomod utions Law

GREENSBURG, La. = Three
Negro students attended their
first classes in previously
all white high school last week.
They we're the first of their race
to integrate a rural louisiana
school.


Four we're scheduled to attend
but one girl decided not to enroll.
Fiery crosses we're burned in
the small town last week, how
ever, there we're no incidents at
the school.


The Negro students we're
transferred under federal court
order. They registered under
heavy guard.

Negro Stud ents


Attend Classes In
All White Schools

James Farmer. national d.
rector of the Congress for Racial
Equality COREY, made several
appearances in the city last
Saturday and Sunday.


Mr.. Farmer spoke at the Phoe-
nix Press Club, Abel Hall and the
Phoenix Jewish Community
Center. He was also interviewed
on the Arizona Round Table on
Channel S TV.


An organizer Of CORE, Farmer
has gained national attention for
his active and personal partici-
pations in freedom rides, voter
registrations and even iailings.


He spoke vehemently against
the nomination of Senator Barry
Goldwater as the Republican
presidential standard bearer. He
said he would be campaigning for
President Johnson.


The CORE leader discussed the
slums of the city and compared
them with some of the worst in
the nation.


Local CORE representatives
have taken housing and job COM
plants to the city council
recently.

According to latest figures the predominant,
Negro inhabited area in South Phoenix, the
ORena0h pre- cinct, contains more Democrat
registered UOteYs than all others except one.


In this area, less attention has been given by
the local Democratic Party than perhaps in
any other area I'm the county. There are no
Democratic clubs nor party attempts TOWARD
interesting area UOteYs, uOhich consist mainly
of Negroes and Mexican-Ame v1cans, until
three or four weeks before elections.


One 1UOn10n deserves commentator for
devoti'zg much of her effort and time toaCayd
deUe lObipg the Democrat Panty in the Okenaah
area. Unfortunately, Mrs. Marie Ogletyee, the
dedicated party aOoYkev, uas only named as an
alternate to the national convention IN Atlantic
City, N. j. Surely, the Democrat panty in
Ad11cOba County could haze glUen her more
recognition as a delegate. She represents
larger and greater ballot potential than many
delegates OhO WeYe named.


Regardless Of the bary's failure to Yecog-
nike the efforts Of Mrs. OgletYee, the cO,anau-
nifty Rn0Us of her W0Yb and respects her
services, regardless Of panty affiliations.

ATLANTA Lester Maddox,
owner of the Pickrick Restaurant,
the scene of several Interrogation
attempts, has closed his bust
ness.

Rather than obey a federal
court order to accept Negroes,
Maddox locked his doors and sold
pickax handles on the street in
front of his cafe for two dollars.

Maddox Closes Restaurant
Sells Pickuxes In Front

Miss Willie Beatrice Jackson daughter of Mr. Mrs.
Jackson 46 So Delaware Chandler became
Robert Charles McFadden Sat-. Aug. s.


Nuptals
l4l E. Jefferson. Phoenix twas double ring ceremony
groom Haywood McFadden of Yuma
He of High School and holds bachelors and
degree from Arizona State University.


The bride graduate Chandler High School she received
bachelors from Arizona State University 1860.
serving u S. Air Mamsthrom
AT Base, Great Falls, Montana


Los Francisco.

Members and friends of ST. John Baptist Church. 1916 S. 18th
Ave. Joined celebrating the 23rd anniversary of Rev. Lawrence
]. Dunbar and his wife.


Pictured from left Rev. Dunbar Mrs Dunbar, Rev. and Mrs.
McCan and Mrs. Crssanda Cooden. Mrs Dunbar holding their
daughter, Lynn.


Mr. Robert Sutton, aid committee chairman
Offering
Others assisting in the Mesdames Mona Watson
program chairman and S. Berry, general chairman.


photo F. Ruffin

Gospel singer Mahala Jackson heads group gospel and
theatrical performers benefit program launch the Dnah
Washington Foundation charitable organization
the late and great blues singer.


The affair." hghlghting Dinah Washington
the anniversary birthday will be held Chcagos
First Church of Deivrance by the Rev. Clarence H.
Cobbs. NPI Photo)
